title: Flight grounded after pilots and cabin crew fail alcohol test
text:
Save 
A flight had to be grounded after both pilots failed an alcohol test. 
The AirBaltic plane had been due to fly from Oslo to Crete, but was delayed for five hours until a sober flight crew could be located. 
The flight was reportedly carrying 109 holidaymakers when it was grounded on Saturday after four of the five crew members failed alcohol tests. 
Telegraph Travel said Norwegian newspaper Dagbladet had reported said police had been tipped off before the plane’s departure by a passenger who suspected the crew had been drinking. 
Police subsequently carried out checks and discovered that both the captain and first officer as well as two of the three flight attendants were over the drink-fly limit. 
The four were all taken into custody. The flight was delayed by around five hours until sober crew members had been located. 
Passengers were reportedly told that the pilot was “unwell”. 
Janis Vanagds, an AirBaltic spokesperson, told the Latvian website LSM that it has a “zero tolerance policy”. 
“Zero tolerance means no alcohol,” Vanags said, “It’s very straightforward - safety is our number one priority. 
“There has been an initial test and that is being followed up with more detailed tests. When we have the results we will take appropriate action. I apologise to all customers who have been affected by this incident.” 
Helena Therese Langeland, a passenger on board, said: “It is surprising that people who have such huge responsibility in their jobs, don’t take it seriously and have so little professionalism.”
